pros: I never thought I'd be happy working for McDonald's but I've been proven wrong. My managers and coworkers are all amazing. The work environment feels close-knit and positive. I'm paid well above my state's minimum wage, receive a free meal daily, get an employee discount and paid vacation days, and have access to other perks. I also do enjoy the work itself and feel appreciated by both my coworkers and the customers.
cons: It can get really hectic at times, especially in rush hour, and that can feel overwhelming. Sometimes customers are rude even when we do everything right for them and there's not much you can do except wait for them to leave. Also people judge you for working at McDonald's and don't value the work you do there.

review_title: Repetitive, "just there for the paycheck" kind of environment
job_title: Cashier and Crew Member in New York, NY
pros:
- Free meal on your break
- 50% on menu items on days you are scheduled
- Very easy to get the hang of each station once you've done it once or twice.
- Paid, on-the-job training from other employees
cons:
- Mind-numbing, repetitive work. Often sat in one station and forced to do that for the entire 8-hour shift.
- Zero incentive to work other than a paycheck. No rewards or recognition for good work.
- Very rude customers at times, which is expected, but no protection for employees unless your manager is willing to defend you.
- Either VERY slow-paced or extremely chaotic (again, as expected, but worth mentioning)
- Lots of roaches and mice, but nobody likes to talk about that
- Have to stand at your station for the entire shift. Legs and feet will eventually go numb in the wrong shoes.
- Only provided with one single uniform set. Do laundry frequently, you WILL smell like fries and burgers constantly (unless you're into that)

pros: There isn’t much to say about this place, it’s already known to be crazy. But my experience working there was not pleasant. I was first scheduled a zoom call interview. After waiting on the zoom call for 30 mins I ended up having to call the store to remind the manager of our interview. She ended up interviewing me right there, on the phone. Then told me I started Saturday morning. Everyone knows it’s always crazy on a Saturday morning at a McDonald’s. Everyone loves there pancakes and syrup. I walked in with everything I needed and asked an employee if I could speak to a manager. She pointed me to the back and I knocked and walked in. The manager was nice, asked for what she needed and proceeded to throw me onto the battle field. At this point I was 16 years old. Of course I knew how to take orders and bag items.. just not with there computers. Ended up maybe messing up a few orders.. and proceeded to get yelled at by the boss?.. not really sure. Never worked another Saturday morning after that.
cons: I really enjoyed working there after I managed to get around working with toxic coworkers. Loved working w everyone else, super calm. Ended up really loving the flow of everything, big rush than clean. After a week I was able to get the flow of everything.

pros:
-You can always get more hours
-Repetitive, you know what to expect on the daily
-Easy to learn
cons:
-Harder to reduce hours 
-Stressful to request time off, you should plan very far ahead
-Pay can be low relative to workload (depending on where you live)
-Often times poor communication/planning between managers leading to understaffed or overstaffed shifts, bad station rotations, too early or late breaks
-Always a possibility of a toxic environment, whether it is staff or management
-Dealing with bad customers can be stressful, expect it to happen often
-Lack of training makes it difficult to rotate employees properly, expect to be on one or two stations for the entire shift
-Corporate is out of touch, makes employees complete irrelevant electronic learning material, sometimes expected to do at home

cons: Being a manager for Mcdonalds is a 40 hours a week babysitting job. You deal with sixteen year olds that either don't have to work or are too lazy to work. You do get the diamonds in the rough that come out on top of the bad crew and carry everybody through out the shift. Only these people are already fed up with the company so they last another month maybe a year if your lucky then they quit. The turn over is absolutely atrocious. You are generally training people rather than leading the shift.

review_title: For a minimum wage job it is better than I had been led to believe from the outside.
pros:
* Even as a fulltime employee the management structure is "supposed" to allow you to take time off when you need or want with at least 2 weeks notice. There are some in the company that take whole months off to travel and visit their home countries even in semi management positions. 

* Emerging technology is making the job easier and more manageable.
cons:
* Integrating new technology with workers that have been set in their ways of doing things for years has created resentment between those who liked it the old way and those who are new, and can at times subvert the efforts of those who try to adopt the new techniques in preforming their jobs. 

* Creating systems that increase production without automating systems that produce the materials necessary to complete that new production standard leads to shortages of necessary materials needed to complete the job.

* Like with many companies the job description that you are given is more of a guideline than a contract of your responsibilities and you are often required to preform tasks that are far outside your job description while also being held to the standard of fulfilling all of your job requirements as well. 

* It is difficult to maintain a flow state while working as your concentration is broken by excessively loud timers for every job going off all day that sound very similar leaving you with a sense that you need to look or check to make sure it isn't one of your tasks being alerted.
